Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to get enough rice output.

loans.name: Elene

texts.en:
Elene is 51 years old. She lives in Adigeni district with husband, Temur, her 29-year-old son and her daughter in-law. Elene requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The family owns a small plot of land where potatoes are grown. Harvested products are sold locally at the markets. They also have a Georgia bread bakery. Elene’s husband, Temur, is baking the bread and sells it from the bakery. Elene’s son is an artisan. He is working on private orders and brings additional income into the family. 

Elene requested a loan from Credo to restart a family business. Her loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Elene will purchase grocery stock to open a grocery shop. Elene used to have a shop before and now wants to restart it again. As she is already experienced in this field, Elene will work hard and make her business successful. She will reinvest the profit and purchase more stock of groceries to offer better choice of products to her clients. This will increase her income, and Elene will be able to provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To purchase grocery stock to open a grocery shop.

loans.name: Ara

texts.ru:
Ара родился и живет в городе Капан.Ему 43 года и он проживает с матерью и женой. 
Долгие годы Ара работает водителем. Уже несколько лет он водитель такси и на собственной машине осуществляет частные перевозки по всей Сюникской области. 
Ара имеет множество клиентов в городах Капан и Каджаран. Как таксист у Ара в Капане хорошая репутация и его все клиенты доверяют и предпочитают воспользоваться услугами Ара у такси услуг которого цены значительно ниже чем обычные. 
Ара просит кредит от Кива на сумму 450.000 Армянских драм для ремонта  своего автомобиля, который давно нуждается в технической обновлении. .
texts.en: Ara was born and still lives in the city of Kapan. He is 43 years old and lives with his wife and mother. For a while now Ara has been working as a driver. In the last few years he has been offering taxi services in the entire Syunik district using his own car. Ara has many regular clients in Kapan and Kadjaran cities. He has a good reputation as a taxi driver and his clients trust him. They prefer to use his services because his prices are significantly lower then the competition. Ara is requesting a loan from Kiva of 450,000 Armenian drahm so that he can repair his taxi cab, which he has been putting off for some time.

loans.use: To repair his car, which  needs  technical upgrading.

loans.name: Azamat

texts.ru: Азамату 30 лет. Он с женой, двумя сыном и дочерью живет в районе Шахритус на юго-западе Таджикистана. Климат района прекрасно позволяет разводить здесь скот. Азамат при дворе имеет крупнорогатый скот, с которых получает молочные продукты и мясо для потребления семьи. Так как у него есть опыт в разведении скота, он хочет сделать на этом свой бизнес. Азамат намерен заняться куплей и продажей крупнорогатого скота. Чтобы осуществить свою цель он обратился за кредитом. Азамат берет кредит для начала нового бизнеса - для купли и продажи крупнорогатого скота
texts.en:
Azamar is 30 years old. He lives in Shahrituz region together with his wife, two sons and  a daughter, which is located in south western Tajikistan. The region's climate is ideal for raising cattle. Azamar keeps a few cows on his property for personal production of milk and meat. As Azamar has some experience raising cattle he wants to make it his business and raise and sell cattle for a living. He has turned to Kiva for a loan to finance his venture.



замату 30 лет. Он с женой, двумя сыном и дочерью живет в районе Шахритус на юго-западе Таджикистана. Климат района прекрасно позволяет разводить здесь скот. Азамат при дворе имеет крупнорогатый скот, с которых получает молочные продукты и мясо для потребления семьи. Так как у него есть опыт в разведении скота, он хочет сделать на этом свой бизнес. Азамат намерен заняться куплей и продажей крупнорогатого скота. Чтобы осуществить свою цель он обратился за кредитом. Азамат берет кредит для начала нового бизнеса - для купли и продажи крупнорогатого скота

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Irina

texts.ru:
Ирина – вдова, она живет в селе Водяное. Еще 30 лет назад решила заниматься сельским хозяйством на своем земельном участке. Стала выращивать овощи, а именно помидоры, огурцы и редис. Ирина всю жизнь проработала фельдшером на скорой помощи, знает все село. Сейчас она на пенсии, муж умер. Пенсия у Ирины маленькая, прожить на нее трудно, поэтому она занимается хозяйством вместе с сыном. На сегодняшний день имеет доход с огорода в 63 000 гривен. 
Ирина обратилась к КИВА за финансовой помощью в 10 000 гривен для того, чтобы закупить удобрения, пленку, а также приобрести брус, проволоку и рейку для новой теплицы. В прошлом году купили дом в селе Днепровка и стали строить там теплицу, но немного не хватило средств, чтобы закончить. В следующем году Ирина надеется построить еще одну теплицу.
texts.en:
Irina is a widow who lives in Vodyanovo village. She has been farming on her home plot for 30 years, primarily growing vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumbers and radishes. She in now retired but has worked as a nurse for emergency room all her life. The entire village knows her well. Irina's husband passed away and her own pension is small so to make a living she farms with her son. Currently her profits from farming are 63 000 grivn.

Irina has turned to Kiva for a loan of 10000 grivn to purchase fertilizer as well as supplies for another greenhouse. Last year she and her son bought another house in Dneprovka village and were buildings greenhouse there but ran out of money. They are hoping to complete the greenhouse this year. Next year Irina is planning to build another one.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for green house repair

loans.name: John Mario

texts.es:
John de 46 años de edad, se dedica desde hace 20 años a la venta de artículos y repuestos relacionados con la electricidad, al tiempo que presta sus servicios en la misma área.  Inició su negocio desde su vivienda y con el transcurrir del tiempo sus ventas han incrementado, generando la oportunidad de abrir un local y expandirse en el mercado local. 
En la actualidad se encuentra solicitando un crédito para la compra de una motocicleta para realizar los domicilios de su negocio, lo que le permitirá aumentar las ventas y reducir los costos de transporte.
Sueña con poder brindarle a su familia una vivienda y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
John is 46 and has sold electronic goods and replacement parts for the past twenty years. At the same time, he also lends his services in electronics. He started his business in his home, and with the passing of time, his sales have increased, creating the opportunity to open a location and expand his place in the local market. 

He is currently requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle so he can get to homes for his business, which would help him increase sales and reduce transportation costs. 

His dream is to offer his family their own home and a better quality of life.

loans.use: purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Superacion Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario  SUPERACION  está  compuesto por dos integrantes mujeres, la  coordinadora del  grupo  es la Sra. Maria tiene 54 años, ella se dedica a la venta de productos de primera necesidad en su  tienda de barrio que se encuentran en la zona de Villa Fátima este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución,  va a usar este préstamo  para la compra de mercadería como abarrotes y refrescos para surtir su negocio,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es la mucha demanda que tiene y es ahí donde incrementa sus ventas, y necesita surtir su mercadería la Sra. Maria enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia ya que existen varias tiendas en la zona, va a utilizar los beneficios en la compra de mas mercadería para surtir su tienda y seguir creciendo más cada día, su deseo para  su negocio es de seguir vendiendo y tener una tienda más grande y surtida, así poder hacer crecer su negocio.
texts.en: The Superacion group is made up of two female members. The leader is Miss Maria, age 54, who owns a corner store that sells basic items in the Villa Fátima neighborhood. This loan will be her first with this lender and she plans to use it to buy merchandise, such as packaged foods and soft drinks to stock her store. The reason she is taking out this loan is the intense demand that she sees and the increasing sales that go with it, making it necessary for her to stock up on merchandise. Maria faces a number of challenges in her business, including the competition from the many other stores in her area. She will use the gains from this new merchandise to keep her store stocked and keep on growing day by day. Her business goals are to be able to keep up with sales and have a bigger and better stocked store, so she can grow her business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise, such as packaged foods and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy balanced animal feed for her farm.

loans.name: Mujeres Formales Group

texts.es: Mujeres Formales realiza por quinta vez un préstamo con el objetivo de mantener estable su negocio que ha crecido mucho desde el primer préstamo que obtuvieron. Claire espera aprender a confeccionar nuesvos estilos de ropa para así ofrecer variedad a sus clientes y que de esta forma sus ingresos incrementen. Para ella el mayor obstáculo que ha tenido que atravesar en su vida es educar sola a su hijo, pero que también ha sido una inspiración para seguir adelante en su trabajo sin darse por vencida. Las actividades que realiza en el día son muy bien distribuidas, pues en la mañana vende las prendas de ropa ya sea en su domicilio o en el domicilio de sus clientes y en la tarde realiza cobranzas de los saldos pedientes que sus clientes tienen con ella. Hortencia y Jesús desean comprar telas y productos respectivamente para así poder mejorar sus ventas en temporada de inicio de clases en donde son demandados los uniformes para los escolares que siempre prefieren que sean confeccionados a la medida de cada persona. Es así como este grupo de mujeres luchadoras continúa luchando por sus sueños.
texts.en:
Mujeres Formales [Professional Women] is taking out its fifth loan with the goal of keeping a business stable that has grown a lot since its first loan. Claire hopes to learn how to craft new clothing styles so as to provide her customers with variety and keep her revenues up. For her, the biggest challenge in her life has been providing an education for her only son. That said, he's been an inspiration to her to always keep moving ahead in her work and never give up. Her daily routine takes her in many directions; selling clothes in the mornings whether in her house or at a customer's home, and in the afternoons focussing on collecting payments from customers who owe her installments.    

Hortencia and Jesús hope to buy their own materials in order to improve their sales in the back to school season when uniforms are in high demand and people always want to have them tailored to the student. This is how this group of determined women keeps on striving for their dreams.

loans.use: To buy clothing and raw materials.

loans.name: Silvia Yanira

texts.es: Doña Silvia de 37 años de edad vive con sus 3 hijos de 13, 12, 6 años de edad en casa de un familiar, desde hace 3 años tiene una pequeña tienda con las ganacias que obtiene de las ventas logra sacar adelante a sus hijos, quiere surtir su tienda pero no tiene capital para poder realizarlo, por eso solicita un credito que le permita poder comprar mas mercaderia y asi poder tener mejores ganancias y seguirle dando a sus hijos lo que necesitan y tener una mejor estabilidad economica.
texts.en: Silvia, 37, lives with her three chidlren, ages 13, 12 and 6, in the family home.  For three years she has been running a grocery store and using the sales profits to support her children.  She wants to stock the store but does not have enough capital to do so.  That is why she is requesting a loan to buy merchandise and increase her profits.  This will allow her to give her children what they need and improve economic stability.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Yessenia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Yesenia, habita en la ciudad de Granada, tiene 35 años de edad, madre de 2 hijos de 18 y 17 años de edad, solo aprobó la primaria, se dedica a la costura y elaboración de bordados a mano.
Ella inicio este oficio desde muy temprana edad pues miraba a su madre trabajar de costurera diario se ponía a elaborar piezas para vender. Cuando su madre salía a comercializar la ropa que elaboraba Yesenia agarraba la máquina y se ponía a practicar hasta que logro aprender  y los 15 años ya estaba trabajando junto con su madre. Actualmente ya tiene su propia clientela, gracias a este negocio mantiene a su madre y a sus hijos. Ella se especializa en bordados hechos a manos, elabora figuras típicas de colores muy vistosos que llaman la atención de extranjeros que visitan la ciudad es así como se gana la vida a diario. 
Ella necesita comprar materia prima tales como telas, seda, hilos de colores diferentes. Uno de sus planes es dar a conocer sus productos atravez de ferias, mercados  para captar más clientes pues considera que el bordado que realiza es un arte que hace con mucho amor y talento.
texts.en:
Yesenia, 35, lives in the city of Granada and has two children, ages 18 and 17.  She received an elementary education and works as a seamstress who also does hand embroidery.

She learned the trade at a very young age because she used to watch her mother sewing every day and selling her products.  When her mother would go out to sell the clothing she had made Yesenia would sit at the sewing machine and practice until she learned how to sew.  At age 15, she began working alongside her mother.

Now she has her own clientele and, thanks to her business, is able to support her mother and her children.  She specializes in handmade embroidery and makes the typical figures that are so colorful and attract the attention of foreigners visiting the city.  This is how she earns a living.

She is in need of raw materials such as fabric, silk, and different colored thread.  One of the plans she has is to exhibit her goods at fairs and markets to attract more customers.  She believes her embroidery is an art created with a lot of love and talent.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as fabric, silk, and different colored thread.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy natural products.

loans.name: Eveling Patricia

texts.es: Eveling, de 30 años de edad soltera trabaja como ejecutiva de ventas para una empresa privada, estudia la carrera de contaduría pública y finanzas y de su salario cubre los gastos de sus estudios, para ella su carrera es muy importante porque puede contribuir al país con sus conocimientos. El crédito que solicita es para poder pagar el curso de titulación, ya que con su salario no le alcanza para pagar este gasto que tiene un alto costo, Eveling agradece el apoyo que le brindan Kiva y Afodenic a estudiantes de bajos recursos para el progreso tanto económico como profesional.
texts.en:
Eveling, 30, is single and works as a sales executive for a private company.  She is studying public accounting and finance and her salary covers her education costs.  Her degree is very important to her because she will be able to contribute her knowledge to the country once she has it.

The loan she is requesting is to pày for her final degree course which is very expensive and her salary does not cover it.  Eveling is grateful for the support from Kiva and Afodenic to low-income students, so they can get ahead both economically and professionally.

loans.use: To pay for education costs.

loans.name: Wend Puire Group

texts.fr:
Mme BIBATA représente le groupe WEND PUIRE.  Mariée, elle est mère de 06enfants. Le plus âgé a 26ans et le moins âgé a 12ans. 02 vont  à l’école, elle a 05 personnes à sa  charge.
Mme est restauratrice  depuis 03ans. Elle s’approvisionne à Kombissiri. Ses clients sont les  hommes, les femmes et enfants.
Elle veut s’acheter 02sacs d’haricots pour préparer et vendre.
Avec ses bénéfices, elle désire épargner. Mme ambitionne  contribuer à améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bibata represents the Wend Puire group. She is married and the mother of six children. The oldest is 26 and the youngest is 12 years old. Two go to school and she has five persons to care for.

She has been preparing and selling meals for the past three years. She gets her supplies in Kombissiri. Her customers are men, women and children.

She wants to buy two bags of beans to prepare and sell. She wants to put her profits into savings, and help improve her children's living conditions.

loans.use: buy two bags of beans to prepare and sell.

loans.name: Milena

texts.es:
Milena, de 31 años es una mujer trabajadora. Vive en compañía de sus padres y 7 hermanos a los que apoya en casa de sus padres, donde vive desde que nació.Es una mujer soltera, no se siente mal por ello, pues ayuda a sus hermanos y se supera en su vida, “eso es lo más importante”, afirma. Estudió educación en una Universidad reconocida, ahí obtuvo toda la experiencia necesaria para poder desenvolverse en su carrera. Ahora trabaja en un proyecto de educación del gobierno, donde ella es supervisora de la zona, ahí se encarga de velar el cumplimiento de la alfabetización de los ancianos y adultos que no lograron culminar sus estudios, le gusta mucho esta noble misión y está dichosa de ayudar a las personas a superarse. Pero como los demás pobladores de su zona, también se dedica a la fabricación de ladrillos junto a su hermano, juntos realizan un promedio de 29 millares, no puede dedicarse a tiempo completo, por ello produce muy poco. Pero ahora está pensando contratar peones para que puedan fabricar más ladrillos.  Este es el 5 crédito con KIVA, agradece al apoyo de todos ustedes, ya que obtendrá el préstamo que necesita para lograr sus objetivos. Además promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas.
Milena, invertirá los S/.3000 soles en la compra de arcilla y leña para la fabricación de ladrillos.
texts.en:
Milena, 31 years old, is hard-working.  She lives with her parents and seven siblings, whom she supports in the home that she has lived in since she was born.  Milena is single but this does not bother her as she can help her siblings and can do well in life.  "That's the most important thing", she says.  Milena studies to be a teacher at a well-known university and there she qualified for a career in education.  She now works in a government education programme as a supervisor in the area.  She is responsible for watching over a literary programme for the elderly and adults who did not complete their education.  Milena very much likes this noble mission and she is happy to help people overcome difficulties.  However, like others living in the area, Milena also makes a living making bricks with her brother. Together they make 29,000 bricks but they cannot do this full-time so this is very few bricks.  Now, however, Milena and her brother are thinking of hiring labourers so as to produce more bricks.  This will be Milena's fifth loan with Kiva and she is grateful for all your support as the loan will help her to achieve her objectives.  Milena promises to make her repayments on time.

Milena will invest the 3000 Nuevo Soles in buying clay and firewood to make bricks.

loans.use: to buy clay and firewood.

loans.name: Pupusa Group

texts.es:
Amparo es una mujer de 31 años, creció en un hogar de escasos recursos en el cual recibió mucho apoyo, pero lamentablemente tuvo que dejar sus estudios al terminar la escuela primaria en donde obtuvo los conocimientos básicos que le ayudan hasta la actualidad a llevar a cabo su negocio. Es una mujer que ha luchado cada día para salir adelante con su familia, tiene dos hijos quienes ya han tomado diferentes rumbos de vida pero se han formado con la educación que Amparo no tuvo la oportunidad de conseguir. Esta mujer emprendedora vive en el centro de Santo Domingo la ciudad capital de la Provincia de Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas, un lugar que  tiene un comercio muy activo ya que se ha convertido en un puerto terrestre de intercambio entre sierra y costa de Ecuador. Esta parroquia tiene varias viviendas de cemento y mixtas de madera con cemento. Tiene un río que es muy visitado y en donde los turistas y habitantes practican varios deportes y además tienen la oportunidad de conocer una cultura tsáchila que suele contar sus leyendas a los visitantes en medio de una fogata y camping. Santo Domingo que es la tercera ciudad más habitada de la región, también contribuye con actividades como la agricultura, ganadería, pesca y manufactura, ya que se ha convertido en un puerto terrestre de intercambio comercial entre las regiones Sierra y Costa del país. 
Amparo se dedica a la venta de ropa casual y lo realiza de forma ambulante. Este ha sido su sustento en los últimos años y con lo cual ha podido llevar el sustento a su hogar. Amparo solicita el préstamo para actualizar el tipo de ropa que tiene y aumentar su stock para que así sus ventas crezcan y ella pueda obtener un mejor estilo de vida. 
Amparo lidera el grupo “Pupusa” con 3 emprendedores como ella. José, María y Sara quienes también desean un crecimiento laboral y personal con el préstamo que obtenga. José y maría se dedican a la venta de frutas y verduras y Sara a la comercialización de zapatos casuales y deportivos. Juntos buscan nuevas oportunidades y se han encontrado en el camino con obstáculos como la falta de empleo o la dificultad para el financiamiento de sus negocios, pero sin embargo tienen en común que han luchado por sacar adelante sus vidas y familias con esfuerzo y trabajo diario.
Todos los integrantes de este grupo agradecen la apertura que Fundación Alternativa ha brindado con la facilidad, confianza y asesoría y además animan a quienes alrededor del mundo buscan apoyar en el portal de Kiva a las personas que muchas veces no han tenido la oportunidad de acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Amparo is 31 years old and grew up in a poor but supportive family.  Unfortunately she could not continue her education after primary school but there she learned the basics which still help her in her business today.  Amparo is a woman who fights every day to move forward in life with her family.  She has two children who have taken different paths in life but who both have the education that Amparo was never able to enjoy.  This enterprising woman lives in the centre of Santo Domingo, the capital city of the Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas province.  This is a place with a very active business sector as it has become a land port, used for exchanging goods between the mountainous and coastal regions of Ecuador.  This parish has various houses made or cement or cement and wood.  There is a much visited river where tourists and locals participate in various sports and there is also the possibility of learning about the local "tsáchila" culture as visitors can listen to stories told around a campfire or on the campsite.  Santo Domingo is the third most populated city in the region and local industries include agriculture, cattle raising, fishing and manufacturing in this land port between Ecuador's coastal and mountainous regions.

Amparo makes a living as a street vendor selling casual clothes.  This has been her source of income for the last few years and with it she has been able to support the family.  Amparo is applying for a loan to update her clothes ranges and increase her stock so as to increase her sales.  This will then allow her to improve her lifestyle.

Amparo is the leader of the "Pupusa" group, which has three other entrepreneurs.  José, María and Sara also want to develop their careers and personal lives with this loan.  José and María make a living selling fruit and vegetables and Sara sells casual and sports shoes.  Together they are looking for new opportunities but have come across obstacles such as unemployment or difficulty in financing their businesses.  Nevertheless, they all have in common that they have fought with strength and work every day to bring themselves and their families forward in life.

All of the group's members are grateful for the opportunity that "Fundación Alternativa" is providing - the process is simple for the members and they are being trusted and given advice on their businesses.  The members encourage everyone around the world to support those who do not have access to loans through Kiva.

loans.use: to improve her lifestyle by buying new merchandise.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es: Luz, es una humilde comerciante, originaria de la ciudad de Granada, madre de 4 hijos, ella  se dedica a la venta y elaboración de pan y repostería. Está muy agradecida porque gracias a su primer financiamiento recibido logro comprar materia prima para elaborar pan y repostería variada sus ventas han mejorado, la calidad de su repostería ha mejorado. Se propuesto abrir nuevas rutas de venta para ofrecer su producto y conseguir más clientes. Por ese motivo está solicitando el crédito para comprar  harina, levadura mejorada, aceite, huevos, queso, mantequilla. Espera lograr mejorar su horno artesanal para poder producir más y reducir costos.
texts.en: Luz is a poor businesswoman and originally from the city of Granada.  She is mother to four children and makes a living producing and selling bread and cakes.  Luz is very grateful because, thanks to her first loan, she was able to buy the ingredients to make various breads and cakes.  Her sales improved and the quality of her cakes has also improved.  Luz is proposing opening new avenues for selling her products and gaining more customers.  In order to do this, she is applying for a loan to buy flour, yeast, oil, eggs, cheese and butter.  She hopes to make improvements to her artisan oven so as to produce more and reduce costs.

loans.use: to buy flour, yeast, oil, eggs, cheese and butter.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is 25 years, married to Kitsao, and they have two children. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
For the past year, she has sold coconuts, selling to local customers. Hellen cites high cost of transportation as her major challenge. She dreams of expanding her business and purchasing a motorcycle for distributing coconuts.
With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase five sacks of coconuts. 
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase five sacks of coconuts.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
This is Rosario. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more quantities and varieties of merchandise to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, house hold and business expenditures.
She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy different products like children’s wear, ladies wear, shirts and other merchandise to expand her product inventory. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.
Rosario dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes to give her children a good and quality education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: o pay for children's wear, ladies wear, shirts and other merchandise to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 51 years old. He is married to a farmer and has five children, who all go to school. He has requested a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers to have a better rice harvest. With the profits, he will provide basic needs for his family as well as paying school fees for the children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers to help boost his rice harvest.

loans.name: Jemmimah

texts.en:
Jemmimah is 24 years old, married and has been blessed with two children who are 3 years and eight months old. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.
For the past four years she has operated a retail shop, selling household consumables to local customers. She faces a major challenge of a high cost of transportation in her place of operation.
With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, maize flour, and soft drinks. 
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans, maize flour, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Justin

texts.en:
Justin is 30 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 12 years. He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers, and pay labor costs for maize harvesting. The profits from farming will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pay for labor costs during maize harvesting.

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is 32 years old, married and has been blessed with five children aged between three and fifteen years. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.
For the past five years, she has operated a tailoring business, making school uniforms, and suits for both men and women. Her business challenge is seasonality. She dreams of establishing a rental house in the future.
With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase fabrics, sewing thread and needles for the business. 
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics, thread and needles needed to make uniforms and suits.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is 34 years old, married and has been blessed with four children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past the 6 months she has operated a vegetable kiosk, selling green vegetables, tomatoes and potatoes. She sells primarily to her local neighbors. Juliana dreams of expanding and establishing a shop in the future.
With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes. 
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes.

loans.name: Borolzoibaatar

texts.en: Mr. Borolzoibaatar is 24 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son lives with his mother-in-law in the countryside far from Ulaanbaatar. He and his wife have been running an internet cafe for two years and have accumulated a vast amount of experience in this field. In addition to the internet cafe, they also rent billiard tables to people by the hour. Before helping him, his wife worked as a beauty stylist at salon. The personal computers he uses for his business have deteriorated over the years and need some updating. So he is requesting a loan of 3,200,000 MNT to purchase necessary equipment from China. As a result, he can continue to run his internet cafe without worrying about losing his customers due to poor computer service. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase necessary equipment from China to update his computers.

loans.name: Rose Amina

texts.en:
Rose Amina is a 35-year-old businesswoman who lives in Yei. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of 5 and 12. All of them go to school.
Rose Amina runs a general store, and has been in business for 5 years. She has no employees. She heard about Finance Sudan through other clients. She is taking a loan of 2000 SSP to purchase beans, onions, and many other items. The general store is her only source of income. In 5 years Rose Amina would like to expand her business.
Her major challenges include high prices in the market. Rose Amina says she is happy for the loans given by finance Sudan with the help of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her store.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 35 years old, married to Samson and they have six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past two years, she has sold coconuts. She has been selling wholesale to local customers. She faces a major challenge with the high cost of transportation. Juliet dreams of establishing a vegetable stall in the future.
With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts. 
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 56 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 23 years. He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers, and pay labor costs for the maize harvest. The profits from farming will be used to pay for his children’s school fees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during the maize harvest.

loans.name: Yirigui I Group

texts.fr:
Mme BERTINE représente le groupe YIRIGUI I.  Mariée, elle est mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 24ans et le moins âgé a 22ans. Personne ne va  à l’école, elle a 03 personnes à sa  charge.
Mme fait la transformation (savons) depuis 06ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Tampouy. Ses clients sont les  hommes, les femmes.
Elle veut s’acheter 06litres d’huile, 06litres de beure et 08litres de soude.
Avec ses bénéfices, elle désire épargner. Mme ambitionne  acheter des moules pour fabrication du savon et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Bertine is the representative of the YIRIGUI I group.  She is married and the mother of two children, aged 24 and 22.  Her children are not in school.  Bertine has three persons in her care.

Bertine has been making soap for six years.  She buys her supplies at the Tampouy market and sells to both men and women.  She wants to buy six liters of oil, six liters of shea butter and eight liters of caustic soda.

She plans to use her profits to strengthen her savings.  Her goal is to buy some molds for the manufacturing of soap and to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy six liters of oil, six liters of shea butter and eight liters of caustic soda.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy compost and alfalfa seeds.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
This is Lina, 43, and a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rogelio and a mother to their children. She together with her husband manages their household while operating the business. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.
Lina maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products from the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and others. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are taking on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2000 in sales every week.
To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 9,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Lina dreams to be successful in her business and hopes to help her family financially. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Sayuni Group

texts.fr: La cliente Alimasi est présidente du groupe Sayuni, entrepreneur, âgée de 41 ans et mère de 6 enfants. son conjoint est un militaire. parmi ses enfants, il y a ceux qui sont déjà mariés. La cliente est vendeuse des divers. Elle installe ses produits a son domicile.  ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d'acheter les bijoux, souliers dames, habits, lotions de beauté, savons, etc. Dans le futur, la cliente souhaite acheter une parcelle et y construire une maison d'habitation. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit.
texts.en:
Alimasi is an entrepreneur and the president of Sayuni Group. She's 41 years old and the mother of six children. Her husband is in the military. Some of her children are already married.

She sells various items at her home. This new loan will be used to buy jewelry, women's shoes, clothing, beauty lotions, soaps, etc.

In the future, she wishes to buy a land lot and build a living house. She thanks Kiva's partner, Hekima, for its support with microloans.

loans.use: to buy jewelry, women's shoes, clothing, beauty lotions, soaps, etc

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Umoja Ni Nguvu Group

texts.fr: La cliente Kito kalimbiro est présidente  du  groupement d’affaire  Umoja ni nguvu, jeune entrepreneur,  âgée de 30  ans, mariée et mère de 9 enfants dont 3 étudient et les autres n’étudient pas faute de moyens financiers. Son conjoint est un vendeur de carburant (pétrole, gazole, kérosène, etc.). La cliente est vendeuse de légumes. Elle commença cette affaire avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Plus tard, elle bénéficia des fonds additionnels de crédit de l’IMF Hekima.  Il ya 10 ans, elle exerce cette activité. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter  les légumes à marchander.  Les détériorations,   et sécheresses  sont de défis majeurs pour son activité.  Elle souhaite accroitre son capital, scolariser tous ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit.
texts.en:
Kito Kalimbiro, the president of the business association Umoja Ni Nguvu, is a young entrepreneur, 30 years old, married and the mother of 9 children of whom only 3 attend school as she does not have the financial means to send the others. Her partner is a fuel merchant (petrol, gasoline, kerosene, etc.)

Kito Kalimbiro is a vegetable merchant. She began this business with funds supplied by her husband. Later, she received additional financing from the microfinance organization IMF Hekima. She began her business 10 years ago.

This new loan will allow Kito Kalimbiro to purchase vegetables for resale. Damage to crops and droughts are major challenges for this business. Kito Kalimbiro hopes to increase her capital and to educate her children. In closing, she heartily thanks Hekima for their support in microfinance.

loans.use: purchase vegetables

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Baraka Office Group

texts.fr: La cliente Sifa est trésorière du groupe d’affaire Baraka office,  entrepreneur, âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants qui étudient tous. Son conjoint est un soudeur. La cliente est vendeuse du sel (en gros). Elle installe ses produits devant son dépôt de vente. En plus, elle est sociétaire d’un salon moderne de coiffure. Elle commença ces affaires avec  son fonds propre constitue dans une tontine. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le crédit de Hekima.  Il ya 15 ans, elle exerce cette activité de coiffure et une année dans la vente du sel. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter 300 box du sel et quelques matériels de salon de coiffure.  Elle souhaite accroitre son capital et poursuivre avec la scolarité de ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit et sa vision d’autonomiser les femmes entrepreneurs.
texts.en:
Sifa is treasurer of the Baraka Office Group. She is a 43-year-old entrepreneur, married with six children all attending school. Her husband is a welder.

She sells salt (wholesale). She displays her products in front of her sales depot. She is also a partner in managing a modern beauty salon. She started these businesses using her own funds which she built up in a tontine (savings association). Later, she was granted a credit loan from Hekima.

She has been running the beauty salon business for 15 years and the wholesale salt business for one year.

This new loan will be used to buy 300 boxes of salt and some equipment for her beauty salon. She wants to increase her capital worth and pursue her children's education.

In the end, she strongly thanks Hekima for its support through micro-financing and its vision of empowering women entrepreneurs.

loans.use: buy 300 boxes of salt and some beauty salon equipment

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Uwezo Group

texts.fr: La cliente Mahene est présidente  du collectif d’affaire  Uwezo, entrepreneur,  âgée de 46  ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Son conjoint est un vendeur de carburant (pétrole, gazole, kérosène, etc.). La cliente est vendeuse de poissons. Elle commença cette affaire avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Plus tard, elle bénéficia des fonds additionnels de crédit de l’IMF Hekima.  Il ya 8 ans révolus, elle exerce cette activité. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter  4 paniers des poissons.  Les pourritures et détériorations, manque de  froid, l’insécurité au long de la route sont de défis majeurs pour son activité.  Elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit.
texts.en:
Mahene is president of the Uwezo Group. She is a 46-year-old entrepreneur, married and the mother of eight children. Her husband is a seller of fuel (gasoline, diesel, kerosene, etc.).

She is a fish merchant. She started the business using her own funds received from her husband. Later she enjoyed additional credit funding through Hekima's MFI. SHe has been running this business for over eight years.

This new loan will be used to buy four baskets of fish. Rot and damage, lack of cooling, insecurity along the road are major challenges for her activity. She wants to provide schooling for her children.

Finally, she strongly thanks Hekima for its support through micro-financing.

loans.use: buy four baskets of fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 43 years old. She is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 28 years. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers, and pay labor costs for maize harvesting. The profits from farming will be used to buy cattle for providing milk.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and pay for the labor costs related to maize farming.

loans.name: Siraj

texts.en:
Siraj is 53 years old. He lives in the small village of Lagodekhi with his wife and three children. Siraj has requested loans from local financial institutions several times to start a family business, but with no success. His loan requests were rejected, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.
The only source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. In particular, they have greenhouse, where cucumbers and tomatoes are grown. They sell the harvested products locally. Besides, they have a plot of agricultural land, where potatoes are grown. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.
Siraj requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the frames of new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisions of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country’s rural poor, which do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit Siraj will purchase a horse. Siraj will go to the local forest and bring wood from the forest with horse. They will sell the collected wood in the village and earn an income. The wood is mainly used by the village population in the oven to heat the houses and cook. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a horse and to help haul wood from the forest to sell in the village.

loans.name: Karisa

texts.en:
Karisa is 52 years old, married and has been blessed with eight children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.
For the past three years he has operated a tea shop, making tea and selling to local customers. He faces a major challenge of stiff competition from other businesses.
With the KES 30,000 he wants to purchase sugar, beans and tea leaves.
He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, beans and tea leaves.

loans.name: Perpetue

texts.en:
Perpetue is 29 years old. She is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 14 years. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers, and pay labor costs to care for their maize crops. The profits from farming will be used to buy a cow for providing milk.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers and pay for labor costs associated with their maize crop.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is from Iraq. He is 31 years old, married and has 3 children. Ali is the only provider for his family.
Ali is a barber. After previously working for many years as an employee at a barber shop, Ali established his own business in 2010 and has gained much experience in this field. Now, Ali has an employee and is well-known in his surrounding area.
Ali is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to install a rolling shutter, outside cover over the door and a display window. In the future, Ali is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so that he will be able to educate his children and provide them a better standard of living.

loans.use: to make improvements on his barber shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase beauty products and cosmetics.

loans.name: Sylveri

texts.en:
Sylveri is 54 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 15 years. He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers, and pay labor costs associated with their maize crop. The profits from farming will be used to build a house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilisers and cover the labor costs associated with his maize crop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics.

loans.name: 3.1.267.01.thiệu Phú Group

texts.en:
Nê, 38, is married with two children. She works in service, making processed food to sell in Thieu Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. She  has been in this business more than 10 years and supports two dependents with her business.

Nê is the group leader of the 3.1.267.01.Thiệu Phú solidarity group, which consists of four members. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make processed food to sell.

This is Nê’s first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. The lack of capital is one of the most critical business difficulties that concern her.

With her business profits, Nê hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to maintain a successful business and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make processed food to sell.

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en:
Ms.Dolgorsuren is a 48 year old married woman who lives with her husband in Darkhan city's outer ger district, which lacks the basic infrastructure of the city. She has three children and all of them are married.  She supports her family by operating a retail stall business at the market while her husband works at local company as an excavator driver.

She usually sells socks and underwear clothes at the market.  Now it is one of the high shopping seasons of the year in Darkhan city, so she is requesting a 1.500.000 MNT loan to purchase more socks and underwear clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell in order to increase her working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Masaka Group

texts.en:
SALAMA who is in her early 50s is married with two children who are still going to school.  She has been running a business of selling charcoal since 2009. She works from 7.00am to 8.00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her 12th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase the charcoal stock and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She used the profit to buy a fridge, a TV set, paid school fees and covered household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal to resell. Her dream is to one  day be able to buy a car.

Salama will share this loan with her loan group "Masaka" with 11 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal to resell.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson, is a  37 year old  married man who has four school going children.  He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  His greatest monthly expense is food and school fees for the family.

For the past three years, he has operated a business of buying and selling livestock; selling at the market to local neighbours.  He faces a major challenge of seasonality and the high cost of transportation in his place of operation. 

With the loan, that he is requesting, he wants to purchase goats and cows for resale.  He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase goats and cows for resale

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 33-years-old Iraqi client, who is married and is the father of 2 children.  Bassam works hard to provide the family income while his wife takes care of their children.

Bassam is a water distributor.  He distributes filtrated mineral water for his neighborhood.  He has been in this field since 2000.  Thank to his wide experience in this field, has is well-known in his surrounding area and has hired 2 employees.

Bassam is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD to buy a new motorcycle in order to take the water jugs to his customers. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so that he may be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle in order to take water jugs to his customers

loans.name: Alhowt Group

texts.en:
This group is called Alhowt.  It consists of four members, Antsar, Amnh, Najeeba and Jameela, who are all females.  All members took a loan of 240,000 YER.

Antsar is a 33 year old married woman who has three children who live together in Aden, Yemen.  She benefited from a previous loan.  She had been working in different businesses where selling mobile recharge cards was part of the business.  Her business has been growing and she intends to enlarge her business so, she applied for a second loan of 60,000 YER from AMB to buy additional mobile recharge cards in order to increase her sales.  All members of this group thank Kiva for financing the first loan.

loans.use: to buy additional mobile recharge cards in order to increase her sales.

loans.name: Hafizakhon

texts.en:
A beautiful woman by the name of Hafizakhon lives in a house which is in bad condition. Her husband is a kind man who works as builder and has a very small salary. They have 2 clever children, 3 and 6. Hafizakhon’s children want to live in a house that is in good condition but her income from farming is not enough to provide that. She must repair all of the rooms of her house: her kitchen, bedroom, living room and hall. She is asking for a loan of 3000 TJS to buy building materials such as cement, wood, and paint to help her repair her house. 

In this way, she will be able to offer her family a better quality of life and moral stability that will allow them to progress. Each month, she will make her payment on time. She awaits your support and mercy.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as cement, wood, and paint.

loans.name: Venantie

texts.en:
Venantie is 38 years old. She is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 13 years. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizer and fund labor costs during maize production to maximize the harvest. The profits from the farming will be used to pay her children's school fees.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and fund labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Saheb

texts.en:
Saheb is a 31-year-old Iraqi client who is married and the father of a single child. 

Saheb owns a small shop and specializes in selling tools and supplies. He has been in this field since 2005 and has gained good experience in what he practices. He now has an employee and has become well-known in his neighborhood.

Saheb is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to renovate his shop by installing a rolling shutter, an external ceiling and signage. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so that he may be able to provide his family better life conditions.

loans.use: to renovate his shop by installing a rolling shutter, an external ceiling and signage.

loans.name: Hussain

texts.en:
Hussain is a 33-year-old married client from Iraq who has a child. Hussain is the sole provider of in the family.

Hussain owns a small shop where he sells slippers. He has been practicing this business since 2011. Now, Hussain, has an employee hired already and has gained good experience in this field and is well known in his surrounding area and has earned an excellent reputation.

Hussain is requesting a loan of 2,400 USD. He will use this loan to install a rolling shutter and a display window for his shop. In the future, Hussain aims to improve his business and increase his profits and take a better care of his family by providing them better living conditions.

loans.use: to install a rolling shutter and a display window for his shop.

loans.name: Kien's Group

texts.en:
Kiên was born in 1990. Her husband and she have a barber shop. From her small business, Kien gains 5,000,000 VND a month. 

She has taken part in SEDA's loan program since 2013. In this first loan cycle, Kien borrowed 5,152,000 VND to buy barber tools, tables and chairs for her barber shop. She always wants to improve her family's living standards.

Other members who are part of Kien's group include the following:
Tuyet is 42 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to raise pigs. 
Hoa is 34 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to repair her house. 
Hau is 49 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to sell food in a market.

loans.use: to buy barber tools, tables and chairs for her barber shop.

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene is 46 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 20 years. 

He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs for getting enough maize returns. The profits from the farming will be used to build a modern house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas 48 years old. He is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 12 years. He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs for getting enough maize returns. The profits from the farming will be used to pay school fees for the children. Currently he has eight children and they all go to schools.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Chinh

texts.en:
Chinh was born in 1953. She has four children who are all married. Chinh and her husband sell construction materials. Her husband’s income is about 4,000,000 Viet Nam Dongs (VND) per month. She earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month.

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND to supply more construction materials. She hopes she can buy more furniture for her house in the future.

loans.use: to supply more construction materials.

loans.name: Nayimi

texts.fr: Nayimi est une femme de 46 ans, célibataire et mère de 2 enfants. Elle possède et gère un mini comptoir de vente des viandes boucanées dans un quartier de la ville depuis 5 ans. elle sollicite ce crédit pour acheter des matières premières telles que un bœuf entier, poissons, etc afin d'augmenter son stock de produits. les bénéfices générés serviront à renforcer son activité, élever ses enfants et acheter un terrain.
texts.en:
Nayimi, age 46, is single and the mother of two children. For five years, she's been running a small stall that she owns in one of her city's quarters, where she sells smoked meat.

She's seeking this loan to buy unprocessed meat, such as an entire ox and fish, in order to bolster her stock of products.

She will use her profits to strengthen her business, raise her children, and buy a land lot.

loans.use: to buy unprocessed meat

loans.name: Charo

texts.en:
Charo, 61, is a married man with 12 children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling from home to his neighbours and passersby. He cites seasonality and delayed payments as a challenge in the business.

With the KES 50,000 he wants to purchase maize flour, beans and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, beans and sugar.

loans.name: Hue

texts.en:
Hue was born in 1985. She has two children who are learning at primary school. Her husband is a driver. His income is about 5,000,000 VND per month. 

Hue has a cafe shop. She makes 6,000,000 dong (VND) a month from it. Her family’s total earnings are about 11,000,000 VND per month.
 
Hue has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle, she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND to buy cups and tables for her cafe. She always wants to raise her children well.

loans.use: to buy cups and tables for her cafe.

loans.name: Nargiz

texts.en:
Nargiz is 62 years old. She lives in the small village of Lagodekhi District. Nargiz is provided with a retirement pension. Nargiz requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only income for her is a 125 Laris (GEL) monthly pension. It is hardly enough for food for her. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

She has a plot of land that is not cultivated. Nargiz requested a loan from Credo to start a family business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Nargiz will cultivate the plot of land and purchase the fertilizers and seeds of maize and eggplant. She will be able to sell the harvested products and generate income, which will enable her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to cultivate the land and purchase fertilizers and and seeds of maize and eggplants.

loans.name: Kitsao

texts.en:
Kitsao is a married man who is 31 years old. He has one child who attends school. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

Kitsao operates a retail shop business, selling to local neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of delayed payments in his business. He dreams of expanding his business premises in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 he wants to purchase sacks of beans, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van was born in 1974. She has two children who are learning at secondary school and high school. Her husband is a driver and earns about 5,000,000 Viet Nam Dongs (VND). She sells fresh fruits. She makes about 5,000,000 (VND) a month from it. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month. 

Van has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle, she borrowed 8,736,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,736,000 VND to buy more fresh fruits to sell. Her dream is to let her children have good careers and enlarge her fresh fruit store.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fruits to sell.

loans.name: Julienne

texts.en:
Julienne, 34, is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 15 years. 

She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs for getting enough maize returns. The profits from the farming will be used to reinvest in the farming.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Imani Group

texts.en:
ABDALLAH, who is in his late 20s, is single with one daughter who goes to school. He has been running two businesses. He sells CDs and DVDs door to door and he is also a broker.  He works from 7:00 am to 7:30 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be his 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he wants to use for buying more stock of CDs and DVDs to sell door to door and also to run his broker business. His dream is to one day be able to own a library.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Imani", made up of eleven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more stock of CDs and DVDs to sell door to door and also to run his broker business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more materials for making doors, etc.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther, 50, is married and has four school-going children. They own a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Esther has operated a business selling paraffin for use in cooking, at retail, to her neighbours. In addition she also operates a phone charging business which earns her another source of income. She faces a challenge of delayed payments hence low profits in her business.

With the loan that she is requesting, she wants to establish rental houses and purchase cement and sand for constructing a small shop for sale of paraffin. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to establish rental houses and purchase cement and sand for constructing a small shop for the sale of paraffin

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
Lam was born in 1958. She has two children. Her older son got married. Her younger one is worker.

To earn a living, Lam has a food stall. She gets 6,000,000 VND per month. Her family’s total earnings are about 14,000,000 VND per month. 

Lam has participated in the Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance (SEDA) credit program since 2010. In the last cycle, she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. 

In this loan cycle, Lam would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND to buy food ingredients for her food stall. She hopes to buy furniture for her house.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients for her food stall.

loans.name: Laurent

texts.en:
Laurent, 41, is married to a farmer and they have been farming maize for 10 years. 

He has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs for getting enough maize returns. The profits from the farming will be used to expand the land where he plants maize.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and pay labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Thao

texts.en:
Thao was born in 1968. She has two children. The older son is a driver. The younger child is learning at high school. Thao and her husband wash motorbikes and cars to earn a living. Her family’s total earnings are about 11,000,000 VND per month. 

Thao has participated in the Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance (SEDA) credit program since 2010. In the last cycle, she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. 

In this loan cycle, Thao would like to borrow 9,632,000 VND to buy more machines for her job. She wants to raise her children well, so they can get a job in the future.

loans.use: to buy more machines for her job.

loans.name: Akbar

texts.en:
Mr. Akbar is a 33-year-old man who lives in Lahore, Pakistan, with his family. He is a father of 4 children. He dreams of providing quality education to his children. 

Since 2000, Akbar has been running a general store, and this store is the only source of income for the family. Presently he is in need of purchasing a variety of products for the store that include rice, flour, milk packs, eggs, soaps, tea packs, shampoos, sugar, etc. To purchase those he has requested a loan amount of 120,000 PKR from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan. Hopefully this loan will be a productive one for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products to sell.

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en:
Haydar is 29 years old, married, and has three children. He is from Iraq and is the sole provider of the family.  Haydar owns a small cafe, where people come to relax, drink coffee, and smoke the famous Arabian Hubble bubble. He has been in this field for more than seven years and established his own business in 2012. Haydar's business grew fast and he now has three employees. He gained an excellent reputation in his surrounding area and is well-known in his neighborhood. 

Haydar is requesting a youth loan for $1,800, which he will use to install a second ceiling for his cafe. Haydar is aiming to expand his business and increase his profits so that he can provide his family with better living standards.

loans.use: to install a second ceiling for his cafe

loans.name: José Antonio

texts.es:
José tiene 44 años de edad, esta casado y tiene cinco hijos. Toda su vida se ha dedicado a trabajar en la agricultura; trabajo que aprendió de su padre y es algo que él ha heredado a sus hijos.  Para comprar los insumos agrícolas, debe viajar por calles en mal estado durante una hora hasta llegar al lugar en donde aborda el autobús que lo conduce al pueblo más cercano. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para preparar el terreno para cultivar el maíz; ya que si no lo hace en este momento la persona que le alquilara le puede dar en alquiler el terreno a otra persona y él no tendrá donde cultivar.  De esta manera, no faltara en su casa por lo menos el maíz y los frijoles. Su dese es mejorar su vivienda ya que esta construida de bahareque y esta deteriorado, por lo que desea mejorarla.
texts.en:
José is 44 years old. He is married and has five children. All of his life he has worked in agriculture, a profession he learned from his father and he has handed down to his children. To buy agricultural supplies, he has to travel on roads that are in a bad state for an hour, when he arrives at a place where he boards the bus, which then takes him to the closest village.

The loan he is requesting from Fundación Campo is to prepare the land to grow corn, since if he does not do so at this moment, the person who will rent to him can rent the land to another person, and he will not have a place to grow his crops.  In this way, his house will at least not be without corn and beans. His greatest dream is to improve his home since it is constructed of wattle and daub and it is deteriorating, which is why he wants to improve it.

loans.use: to prepare the land to grow corn, since if he does not do so at this moment, the person who will rent to him can rent the land to another person, and he will not have a place to raise his crops.

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
Ismoil is a hardworking person who is married and has 3 children whose ages are 18, 15 and 11 years. He has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 25 years. Little by little, with the passing of time, he has perfected his knowledge. Thanks to the animals' good condition, he has managed to win a large number of customers for his business. He sells his animals in the local market. Many of his customers are local butchers who are glad for Ismoil's work. 

He is looking for a loan to buy young cattle. In this way he will be able to offer his customers good animals and continue to make financial progress, providing his household with good earnings. He is asking for a loan of 3,000 USD to buy young cattle for developing his business further. Each month he will make his payments on time. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy cattle for developing his business.

loans.name: Binh

texts.en:
Binh was born in 1985. She has two children who are learning in kindergarten and primary school. Her husband is a driver. His income is about 6,000,000 Viet Nam Dongs (VND) per month. Binh has a food stall to earn a living. She earns about 6,000,000 VND a month, so her family’s total earnings are about 12,000,000 VND per month.

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 8,288,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,736,000 VND to buy more kinds of food to sell in her food stall. She wants her children to go to school until they complete higher education.
